Nos. 14238, 14296, 14964 of 2021, 37, 1055 and 4827 of 2022, decided on July 29, 2022 A. Practice and Procedure - Commercial Courts Act, 2015 - S. 2(1)(c) a b - "Commercial Dispute" - Scope - Clauses (i) to (xxii), held, are not an exhaustive list of commercial disputes - It is for this reason, the expression used is "dispute arising out of'' the transactions and activities specified in (i) c to (xxii) - The key word is "commercial" and the scope of S. 2(1)(c) has to be determined according of nature of transaction or activity - The purpose of the Act is to lay down special and expedited procedure for commercial disputes Dismissing the application, the High Court of Delhi Held: The words used in a statute are to be read and understood in their ordinary meaning. It is true that Section 2(1)(c) of the Commercial Courts Act, 2015 comprises of a list of commercial disputes but it is incorrect that it sets out an exhaustive list of disputes that qualify as commercial disputes. If that were the intent, the words used would simply have been "the following are commercial disputes". Instead, the words used are "arising out of" which means that the source of the dispute must be one of the clauses listed in Section 2(l)(c). The clauses of Section 2(1)(c) do not limit the contours of the dispute that may arise. What would be the actual dispute in respect of ordinary transactions of merchants, or export and import of merchandise, or carriage of goods, or construction and infrastructure, and so on, would remain what arises in the ordinary course between two parties in the course of these engagements and activities. Such a dispute could be a breach of contract or the enforcement of terms of contract entailing recovery not only of the price, but possibly damages; disputes may relate to mutual rights or obligations under joint venture agreements (JVAs) or rights and obligations in respect of consultancy agreements; disputes arising out of technology development agreements could entail rights to the sharing of the know- how and/or confidentiality, and so on. If the disputes are relatable to any of the clauses, the disputes would be clothed with the additional adjective of being commercial in nature. The classification has been given to make available a special procedure for trial and speedy disposal of such disputes that impact economic activity. (Para 43) B. Practice and Procedure - Commercial Courts Act, 2015 - S. 2(1) b (c), Expln. - Commercial Dispute - Composite suit seeking commercial and non-commercial reliefs - Intertwined reliefs - Whether non-commercial reliefs can be adjudicated by jurisdictional court - Held, the Expression "dispute arising out of'' used in S. 2(1)(c) and the explanation points out that composite suit is maintainable before commercial court - On facts found that the plaintiff was essentially aggrieved by copyright violation and denigration c of its commercial reputation though relief against defamation was also sought d e f g - Held, the composite suit was maintainable - Civil Procedure Code, 1908 - Or. 2 R. 2 - Copyright Act, 1957 - Ss. 13 and 14 - Words and Phrases - "Arising out of'' - Interpretation Held: The suit is not just for relief against defamation, which would certainly not constitute a commercial suit but is one in which the violation of the intellectual property rights, namely, in copyright, has allegedly resulted in defamation/ commercial disparagement also. The cause of action is the same, namely, the uploading of the videos on You Tube and articles and other content on the website of the defendants' website as well as on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram. To hold that the plaintiff would have to limit its relief before the commercial court only to the extent of violation of intellectual property rights and must be asked to approach the civil court for relief qua defamation, etc., is against the objective of Order 2 Rule 2 CPC, particularly to avoid conflicting judgments . The purpose of the procedure is to facilitate disposal and cannot be intended to complicate matters for a litigant. (Para 49) Jasper Infotech (P) Ltd. v. DeepakAnand, 2015 SCC OnLine Del 14398, cited The relief in respect of copyright violations can be sought only before the commercial court in view of the clause (xvii) of Section 2(1)(c) of the Commercial Courts Act, 2015. If the other reliefs claimed by the plaintiff "arise" out of such intellectual property rights, the commercial court has the jurisdiction to try the suit. "Arising out of", on a plain reading, would cover situations such as in the present case, where the reliefs are so closely intertwined, where disparagement is alleged by the very use and portrayal of the copyrighted content of the plaintiff by the defendants. (Para 51) The dispute at hand is a commercial dispute and the commercial court has jurisdiction to try the suit. (Para 52) D. The plaintiff creates programmes for broadcast on its television channels and the social media. A similar exercise is undertaken by the defendants on their social media platforms. They communicate with the public and are broadcasters. The question whether there can be copyright within such programmes, is not being considered here as it is not in issue. (Para 55) E. Intellectual Property - Copyright - Copyright Act, 1957 - Ss. 37, 52, 39, 2(ff) and 2(m)(iv) - Copyright - Broadcasting rights - Comparison - Communication to public - Fair dealing - Held, first producer of the contents has copyright or broadcasting rights - Their circulation over electronic or social media amount to communication to public which is regulated by law - Both kinds of rights admit exception of fair dealing - The case law relating to fair dealing under S. 52 can be considering for issues relating to infringement of broadcasting rights - Words and Phrases - "Fair dealing" - Interpretation/application Held: The broadcasting rights in terms of Sections 37 and 39 are akin to Section 52 of the Copyright Act, 1957 which also provides that certain acts do not constitute infringement of copyright. Both sections prescribe that use which amounts to fair dealing would not amount to infringement of either broadcast reproduction rights or copyright. (Para 57) The programmes produced by the plaintiff, as well as the defendants whether through TV channels or on YouTube, are communication to the public. For the purpose of such a communication, sound and visual images are used. The one who first creates a programme for communication to the publicis the original creator and is entitled to the same protection against unauthorised reproduction as in respect of a literary, dramatic, musical or artistic work. The original creator being the first broadcaster is vested with the reproduction rights. No one else can reproduce it without licence. The exception is Section 39 read with Section 52 of the Copyright Act, 1957. The judicial pronouncements in respect of literary, dramatic.musical or artistic work, cinematographic film or sound recording, particularly, to determine the question of infringement of rights and defence of fair dealing, may be looked into profitably, even while considering broadcasting rights and fair dealing under Section 39. Criticism or review of such programmes is both on content and the reporting of such current events and current affairs. Reporting entails the coverage of current events and current affairs in a particular manner and style, in keeping with the philosophy of the TV channel or social-media channel. To comment on the act of reporting itself is covered under criticism or review under Sections 52 and 39 of the Copyright Act, 1957. It is protected against infringement. However it would be a question of fact whether the reproduction, which is alleged to be an infringing copy, is protected under Section 39 and/or Section 52 and is actually in the nature of review and criticism. (Para 61) To reproduce content that is broadcast, a licence is required from copyright owner. The only exceptions recognised to this need for licence before reproduction, are provided under Section 39. The excerpts of a broadcast could be rebroadcast if the use is consistent with fair dealing and is in respect of reporting of current events or for bona fide review or teaching or research. The broadcast reproduction right is not infringed even on account of rebroadcast with any necessary adaptations and modifications, which do not constitute infringement of copyright under Section 52. Section 39 has to be read along with Section 52 whereunder, fair dealing for private or personal use, for criticism or review of that work or any other work, or reporting of current events and current affairs, have also been excluded from acts of infringement. There are several other provisions also which exclude acts as non- infringing, but in respect of broadcasting, the additional provisions are Sections 52(l)(z), (za) and (zb). However they have no immediate bearing on the issue involved in the present matter. (Para 62) G. Intellectual Property - Trademarks and Passing Off - Trade Marks Act, 1999 - S. 29(8) - Trade mark infringement - Modes - Disparaging use - Commercial disparagement - Showing competitor's work or mark or product in poor light - Held, amounts to disparagement - Words and Phrases - ''Disparagement" - "Commercial disparagement" Held: The plaintiff and the defendants are competitors inasmuch as both are available to social media users, apart from the fact that the plaintiff is also broadcasting through television channels. Commercial disparagement occurs when one player in the field derides a rival and belittles or discredits or detracts from the reputation of such a rival in respect of its products, services or business. While claiming to be the best, any statement about a competitor's goods, which could be untrue or misleading and is made to influence or tend to influence the public, would amount to disparagement. Civil Procedure Code, 1908 - Or. 39 Rr. 1 and 2 - Temporary injunction - Three parameters - (i) strong prima fade case; (ii) balance of convenience; and (iii) irreparable harm - Stepwise consideration - Held, first parameter if satisfied, has to be followed by consideration of third parameter, namely, competing interests or harms which might be suffered by the rival parties - This determines where the balance of convenience lies - Copyright Act, 1957 - S. 55 - Trade Marks Act, 1999, S. 135 Held: When a court is to consider the grant or refusal of interim injunction, the court has to consider whether the plaintiff has made out a prima facie case in its favour. Even if such a case has been disclosed, the plaintiff is supposed to establish what irreparable harm and injury is suffered by the plaintiff, entitling it to interim protection and which has to be then balanced with the injury that the defendants could suffer, if, after the interim protection is granted against the defendants, the plaintiff loses the suit. It is necessary to determine whether the plaintiff in the present case has succeeded in meeting these three cardinal requirements, namely, prima facie case, irreparable loss and injury and balance of convenience, to be entitled to the injunctions as prayed for. (Para 74) Wander Ltd. v. Antox India (P) Ltd., 1990 Supp SCC 727, relied on Having considered the law regarding copyright/broadcast infringement, fair dealing/fair comment, commercial disparagement and the principles governing grant of interim relief of injunction we may now determine whether the plaintiff is entitled to the interim injunctions as prayed for. However, it is subject to reasonable restrictions, including right to one's reputation. (Para 77) The courts, over a period of time, have pronounced that reputation is an internal and central facet of right to life, as protected under Article 21 of the Constitution. Constitution of India - Arts. 19(1)(a) and 19(2) - Freedom of speech and expression - Scope - Electronic and social media - Intra-media course correction - Practice if desirable - Held, regulatory mechanism is already in place - It is not necessary that one media platform must rectify or moderate the news reporting by the other - Every channel has its own reporting style and priority policy of reporting political and public affairs - General public gets a spectrum of views - This does not call for interference by the competitors - The practice of undermining the reporting of other channels or platforms cannot be countenanced as freedom of speech Held: The court cannot accept the plea defendants' self-appointment regulator of the media content. The mechanisms exist for redressal of grievances relating to content of news channels and for social media content, set up statutorily, including by the platforms themselves. There can be no free for all in the regulatory sphere. Every individual or organisation cannot claim authority to regulate - the chaos can be imagined - there will be only regulators, and no one willing to bide by regulations. But dehors this claim to the status of a regulator, albeit an informal one, what is seen is that basically, the defendants disapprove of the coverage of current news both, in the style, as well as its prioritisation, by the main stream media and TV channels or even the social media platforms. But that may be the opinion of the defendants. The plaintiff may have a contrary view regarding the prioritisation and presentation of current events by the defendants. Ex facie, there is no public interest in the particular programming of the content and broadcast of such content by the defendants. Every media house and channel on TV or the social media platforms, including that of the defendants have their own philosophy, which gets reflected in the manner of reportage and content of the programmes and that is not necessarily a bad thing. (Para 80) What is not acceptable is the assertion of a supervisory right by one media over another, as claimed by defendants. Also hyperbolic is their claim that it is their criticism of the programmes of the main stream media, including of the plaintiff, that push them into rectifying mistakes and that their programmes were invaluable in public interest, and as a corollary, their right to comment and criticise cannot be restricted. (Para 81) Leaving aside such assertions, this Court would accept that the right to comment on content created on social media or on TV channels has also to be recognised as a facet of the right to free speech and expression under Article 19(1) (a). In fact, the availability of a multitude of reporting styles, prioritisation and presentation of events that occur daily, is in public interest, since broadcast is intended to communicate to the public. Dissemination of a spectrum of information by many players results in a better-informed society. Different priorities result in a range of information being readily available with regard to current events. Varied presentations and discussions result in the availability of several shades of opinion before the public which can then come to its own conclusion. It in the interest of the public that every broadcaster has the right of fair comment on current events and of criticism and review, including of the programmes created by others. (Para 82) However, once again, if the right is one to be protected under Article 19(1) (a), it will have to be subjected to reasonable restrictions under Article 19(2). Constitution of India - Arts. 19(1)(a) and 19(2) - Freedom of speech and expression - Scope - Electronic and social media - Intra-media dealings - Comments on the reportings of other media - Fair comments - Held on facts, it is a matter of trial whether comments were fair or disparaging or malicious or made with some ulterior motive Held: It is the case of the plaintiff that the defendants' programmes use words that portray the plaintiff in poor light that they are engaging anchors who could create a riot or their business model was below par since the defendants did not seek advertisement and so on. This is countered by the defendants saying that they were justified in their comment. While determining whether the broadcast or the telecast contained defamatory or disparaging content, it would be necessary to examine the intent and the absence of malice as also the overall effect of the programme commented upon , not just on the subscribers/loyal viewers of the television or the social media channels, but its impact on a reasonable person, who is generally interested in viewing such programmes. Or to put it succinctly, it is a question to be determined by the trial Judge, whether or not the comments and programmes are fair comment or not and that determination can be only after the conclusion of the trial. (Para 84) N. Constitution of India - Arts. 19(1)(a) and 19(2) - Freedom of speech and expression - Scope - Satire - Constructive criticism - Malicious presentation - Held on facts, these are the matters to be determined during detailed trial Held: While freedom of expression would include the art of satire, it must be evident that what was being presented isindeed satire. It must be self-evident and by its very character can never be a case of copyright infringement or defamation or even disparagement. Satire cannot be explained or else it would lose its flavour. Satire allows the satirist to criticise in the harshest of terms and critique actions of all, particularly of those in positions of power and/or authority and leadership. The intention of the satirist is to simultaneously highlight an action and its negative fallout, so that rectificatory action could be taken. It is never intended to disparage or harm reputation and thus is completely devoid of malice. Satirists, at all times in our culture, have been greatly respected and there are several art forms in this country that allowed such criticism of even the rulers in the heydays of monarchy and which art forms still exist. Examples, that come to mind are "Ottamthullal" and the "Chakiyaarkoothu", both in Kerala. Sharp use of language conveys the message intended by the artists, but in a cultured and nuanced manner. Such creative genre must, without doubt, be encouraged and protected. Civil Procedure Code, 1908 - Or. 39 Rr. 1 and 2 - Temporary Injunction - Defamation case - "Truth" pleaded as defence - Held, this adds another dimension in a case where temporary injunction is sought - Truth calls for detailed consideration at trial - Counter reporting of one media platform by the other- On facts held, the dispute practically related to reporting style or prioritisation of the reported news - It warranted detailed trial whether it was an honest act or fair comments or something else Held: The interim injunction is sought at a time when the rival claims are yet to be determined for their merit. Additionally, in the case of defamation, it is also to be seen, what is the defence raised, and if the defence is of truth or justification that has been raised, ordinarily, no injunction would follow as the defendant has to get the opportunity to prove such a defence. In the present case, truth was pleaded, but without disclosing whether the truth relates to the events covered, or the truth of the manner of coverage of current events by the plaintiff, or the truth of the defendants' comments. It does not seem that in the present case, truth is available as a defence. At best, what is portrayed in the defendants' programmes. That opinion is claimed to be, firstly, in the public interest and, secondly, an honest and fair comment. The comments do not seem strictly in public interest, except as a part of the larger picture of the right to express an opinion adding to the availability of myriad such opinions to the public at large. Whether the comments constitute honest and fair comment require trial. (Para 86) P. Similarly to say that one of the anchors was engaged as she had enormous potential for starting a riot, seem disparaging of plaintiff's the capacity to engage capable anchors apart from a questioning of the anchors" own capabilities, and how such statements would be justified by the defendants is not evident. (Para 87) The other suggestive comments that seeking advertisements was bad as a revenue model and that the defendants' model of seeking subscriptions alone ensured a free and unbiased reporting, is a commercial disparagement, as advertisements on TV channels or even social media cannot be a ground for rejecting a channel's view point or reporting. There is no gainsaying that advertisements plays a significant role in informing the public of availability of goods and services and the wide reach of the electronic media and TV channels as also the social media, often lead manufacturers of goods and services to advertise on these platforms and expand their own business. These statements call for justification by the defendants. (Para 88) It cannot be denied that a prima facie case is disclosed but disclosure of a prima facie case alone will not entitle a plaintiff to interim injunction.
